cell.p: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.

This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

Grand Hotel Assouan.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

div.head: DEATHS.
div.p: ARMSTRONG.- On 11th inst. at the Desconesses' Hospital, Alexandria, C.F. Armstrong, of the Coast Guard Administration, ages 35.
BETTIE-- At Assouan, on the 11th inst,. Archibals Campbell Bettie, director of works, Assouan Reservior, aged 31.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT
div.p: The acceptance of the Chirf Judgeship at Shanghai by Judge de Sausmarez has brought up the question as to whether it would not be advisable to have a division of the H.M.'s Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte instituted permanently in Egypt. The Bench, as at present constituted, consists of a judge and an assistant judge, and the area of the judicial operations of these gentlemen embraces the

huge tract of country extending from the southern shores of the Black Sea to the confines of the Sudan, while eastwards it stretches to the Tigris and Euphrates. The British population of Egypt has increased enormously since the judicial functions of the Consulate here were restricted, on the retirement of Sir Charles Cookson, and the cases which come within the purview of the Supreme Consular Court are constantly growing in number and importance. The hardship inflicted on the parties concerned is oftentimes considerable. For example, in the Assouan shooting case, the defendant had to wait for months before his trial, and the mental strain of the suspense must have been very trying. The expense attendant on the judge's journeys to Egypt must come to a considerable sum every yea,r and this would be economised by the establishment of a permanent divisional court of the Supreme Consular Court in Egypt, which could be made to conveniently embrace the Arabian coast of the Red Sea, where shipping cases of some importance occasionally arise. Such an appointment is from every point of view desirable, and a petition on the matter should be addressed to Lord Cromer and the Foreign Office without delay.

div.head: THE SORROWN OF RUSSIA
WIDESPREAD REVOLT
THE REFORM MOVEMENT
div.p: It is estimated that 50 students were wounded yesterday. The rioting was organised by the revolutionary Socialists, and not by the Liberal Reformers. Another demonstration is expected next Tuesday when the trial of M. Plehve's assassin begins. (Reuter.)

The Standard has had an interview with a high Court Official in St. Petersburg who stated that the rioting was nothing compared with the situation in the Provinces. In addition to the excess committed by the reservists at Vitebak and elsewhere, the peasantry are revolting against the Government in Ekaterinoslav, Hazan, and Saratoff. The official added that Court was anxious concerning the issue of the tremendous struggle between Prince Mirski in favour of the reformers, and the reactionary Grand Dukes. It is believed that the Prince will win. (Reuter).

div.head: THE CHINESE RAND
OCCASIONAL DISTURBANCES
div.p: There are occasional disturbances in the Chinese Rand. The Chinese yesterday attacked the Kaffirs at the Witwatersrand mine. There were 4 killed and 88 wounded. (Reuter.)

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
RUSSIAN FLEET DISABLED,
TOWN BEING SHELLED.
ARSENAL IGNITED.
div.p: General Nogi reports, that apart from the battleship Serastopol and some destroyers which are sheltering outside the harbour, the Russian fleet is completely disabled, and a further bombardment of the ships is needless. The Japanese are now shelling the town itself, and inflicting heavy damage. (Reuter.)
The bombardment of Port Arthur has considerg/oly damaged the wireless station on Golden Hill, and has ignited the arsenal. (R.)
News from Port Arthur states that the Russian fleet is disabled. The bombardment is now being confined to the town. (Havas.)

div.head:
GENERAL NEWS
RUSSIAN SHIPS AT CAPETOWN.
div.p: The Russian hospital-ship Orel and a collier have arrived here. (Reuter.)

div.head:
ANGLO-AMERICAN ARBITRATION.
TREATY SIGNED.
div.p: The Anglo-American Arbitration Treaty bas been signed here to-day. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMAN CROWN PRINCE'S MARRIAGE
div.p: The marriage of the Kronprinz will take place on March 22 next. (Havas.)

div.head: THE NOBEL PRIZE.
div.p: One of the Nobel prizes has been awarded to the poet Mistral. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive, who spent yesterday at Marjout, is there to-day. The Khedive and the Khedivah will return to Cairo after having celebrated the anniversary of the birthday of Prince Abdul Mouneim, on the 9th Chawal (16th December). His Highness has conferred the decoration of the 4th Class Osmanieh on El Kaimakam J. S. Liddell Bey, Sudan Civil Administration. ' His Highness has conferred the rank of Sanieh (Bey) on Mohamed Gafar Bey, former. ly of the Nasrieh School, on the occasion of his retirement from the Government service.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: MAHMOUD PASHA SAMI.
The death occurred last night at Cairo of Mahmoud Pasha Sami el Baroudi, one of Arabi's leaders. His funeral takes place this afternoon.
YOUSSEF EFF. IBN ACHOUR.

We regret to announce the death of Youssef Effendi Ibn Achour, the father of Omar Bey Loutfy, the well-known native advocate and professor at, and sub-director of, the Khedivial Law School. The deceased was an Algerian, but a local subject, and was staying at an hotel at Alexandria when he succumbed suddenly yesterday morning. The mortal remains were taken to the house of Said Mohamed el Tiafah by the Mosque of Aboul Abbas at Bab Sidra. The deceased was 55 years of age. We beg to tender our sympathy to Omar Bey Loutfy, who is one of the most promising of the new generation of native legal luminaries and has many English friends in the Ministry of Justice.

div.head: ARRIVALS
div.p: Le paquebot Salazie des Messageries Maritimes arrivé ce matin avait à bord : M. et Mme J. Cormack, Nerazzi, O. S. Prichard, C. R. Mowatt, M. et Mme Morris, Schuhl, Seligmann, col. et Mme Rolleston, Mme Leroy, Dombre, M. et Mme Pellet, V. Green, Mme S. div.head: SANITARY DEPT. ---
div.p: Dr. Chehata Khouzam and Mme Koconio Morou, midwife, have been authorised to practise in Egypt.

div.head: "THE SPHINX”
div.p: of next Saturday will contain matter that will be of particular interest to tourists, such as visitors' lists, etc.

div.head: QUARANTINE.-
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Port Said are now submitted to a medical inspection.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS Dogs
div.p: found in the Minet-el-Bagsal and Ramleh districts on the 17th inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: H.H.S. Aida,
div.p: of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, left Alexandria at 2 o'clock this morning for El Amaid, Port Said, and the Red Sea.

div.head: HASHISH SEIZURE.--
div.p: The Coast Guards Administration has made a seizure of 1,154 kilos of hashish in the Western desert, near Minieh province.

div.head: THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: has approved the Budget for 1905 and has decided to congratulate the Government on having followed its suggestions.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA CHORAL UNION
div.p: practices will not be resumed until after the 'Xmas festivities. Notices will be sent round to the members fixing the next practice.

div.head: AN IMMENSE AUTO-CAR,
div.p: with seating capacity for 15 persons, is now running between Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palace hotels. If the service proves satisfactory, excursions to near-by points of interest have been proposed.

div.head: PRESERVATION OF ARABIC MONUMENTS. --
div.p: The twentieth publication of the Committee for the Preservation of Memorials of Arabic Art has just been issued. It contains a report of the work done in 1903.

div.head: Cairo MUSICAL AND DRAMATIC SOCIETY.
div.p: Residents in Cairo of a musical or dramatic turn should peruse the advertisement under this heading which appears on page 5. Assistance is desired in getting up concerts, dramatic performances, and an amateur orchestra.

div.head: EXTRAORDINARY LONGEVITY. —
div.p: An extraordinary case of longevity is reported from Shoubra Namla, in the Gharbieh province, where an inhabitant has reached the patriarchal age of 125. The man's age is vouched for by the omdeh of the village, so it must be correct.

div.head: CUSTOMS RECEIPTS.—
div.p: The receipts of the Customs Administration during the month of November amounted to £.E. 325,192, of which £.E. 188,789 was derived from imports and £.E. 25,897 from exports, while miscellaneous receipts amounted to £.E. 1,636. Tobacco accounted for £.E. 114,673.

div.head: RAMADAN IN LONDON.—
div.p: By special permission of the First Commissioner of Works, and for the purpose of following the Moslem custom of offering an open-air prayer to celebrate the Feast after the Fast of Ramadan, the PanIslamic Society held a prayer meeting in Hyde Park, London, last Friday morning at eleven o'clock.

div.head: INSPECTION.-
div.p: Mr. P. Machell has left Cairo for an inspection in the El Laboon district, Fayoum province, which will last about a week. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior spent yesterday morning at Medinet el-Fayoum, where he enquired into the working of the ghaffir service. He left afterwards for El Laboon.

div.head: ZINZINIA THEATRE
"I PURITANI."
div.p: The above opera, which was produced at Paris in 1835, was the final work of the celebrated composer Bellini, who died at the early age of 33. The music is melodious and passionate, the score soft and majestic. The interpretation of the work yesterday evening WAS, frankly, mediocre. The tenor Andreini sang well the admirable romances and duos which frequently occur; the part of Lord Arthur demands, however, a tenor with a more extended scope of voice. The baritone Nani and the bass Walter, in the roles of Sir George and Sir Richard Forth, were very successful. The celebrated duet in the 3rd act had to be repeated by them. Signa. A. Tromber possesses a soprano voice which she exercises with incomparable agility. She was greatly applauded in the 3rd |act.

div.head: VERDI THEATRE
"FAUST."
div.p: On the whole a good performance, the mise en scène being as good as ever and the orchestra in fine form. Faust was a little uninteresting, and Siebel, to put it mildly, disappointing, but Siga. Malaspina, after beginning a little nervously, sang really well as Marguerite, though there was the least suspicion of strain about her high note. Mephistopheles (Sig. Badini) began magnificently, and his rendering of the “Route du Veau d'or” was one of the best we have heard, but he got out of tune curiously out of tune, at the close of the serenade, the one blot on what was otherwise a very fine performance. The soldiers' chorus was as well received as ever, but we regret that the song assigned to Siebel in the 4th act, and "cut" by almost every conductor, was given at all. In the first place, it is a song for the drawing-room, not the opera, and in the second, it was manifestly impossible for Siebel to do justice to it. The "apotheosis" bordered on the comic.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET
PASSAGE OF 3RD DIVISION
div.p: We hear that, in the event of the 3rd Division of the Baltic Fleet passing through the Canal, the precautionary measures taken by the Government will be of a less extensive nature than they were during Admiral Folkersahm's transit. The groundlessness of the Russian apprehensions of Japanese spies and mine-layers assailing their ships in the canal appears to have been recognised by the Russian Admiralty

div.head: NEW FINANCIAL ENTERPRISE
div.p: An English Trust has been formed at Alexandria for undertaking developing business generally as it may occur. The capital is £200,000, which will be called up when it is wanted. There will be no public issue until next January. Mr. Richard Abdy, late SubGovernor of the National Bank of Egypt, is the managing director, and Mr. Mieli, chief accountant of the National Bank at Alexandria, is to undertake the management of the new concern. The capital has already been guaranteed.

div.head: ATTEMPTED HIGHWAY ROBBERY
div.p: A singularly daring attempt at highway robbery has been frustrated by the Assiout police. It appears that a local Capt, a business man of the town, was believed to be in the habit of taking large sums of money with him while driving home from his business house at night. A gang of criminals planned to attack his carriage and rob him at a stop on the Hamra road not very far from the railway station, where a high dura crop was growing on each side and afforded an excellent hiding-place and means of escape. The police were warned of the projected attack and after several nights their vigilance was rewarded. Four policemen in civilian dress, driving slowly in a covered carriage past the dura field, were suddenly assailed by the robbers, one of whom was overpowered and captured in the scuffle that followed. The rest escaped, after an exchange of shots, into the corn.

div.head: YOUSBASHI ARMSTRONG
div.p: The funeral of the late Yousbashi Armstrong took place yesterday at Alexandria. Among those who followed the mortal remains of the deceased to the British Protestant Cemetery were Rear| Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, K.C.M.G., Director-General of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, Kaimakam Sheehan Bey, Stafi Inspector of the Coast Guards Administration, Major Ludlow, D.A.A.G., Bimbashi Sandwith, Binbashi Grogan, Sagh. Morice, Sagh. Mustapha Effendi and Sayh. Stagni, of the Coast Guards Administration, Yousbashi Ramanda, of the Alexandria City Police, Mrs. Morice, Mrs. Birch, Bimbashi Cobbe, Sub-Commandant of the City Police, Sagh. D'Aubuz, of the police, Yousbashi Watt, of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, Mr. Willie Birch, and many others. Military honours were paid by a detach intent of the Coastguard Administration's land service.

div.head: OUR SOLDIERS' GRAVES AY HELOUAN
div.p: A Helouan correspondent writes : —A few years ago you had a strongly-worded article on the state of our Soldiers' graves at Helouan. But the condition of these graves at the present time is disgraceful. Old petroleum and milk tins and native refuse lie about on the graves. The names are illegible and the general state of the up-keep of the sacred spot leaves everything to be desired. There is a company of engineers stationed there for the time being, and I am surprised they have no time to spare to tend their comrades' neglected resting places.

div.head: THE TOWN OF SUEZ
div.p: For almost two years Suez had been anxiously awaiting the electric light installation, and finally the streets were brilliantly lighted up & couple of months ago, the inhabitants being delighted with the result. It now appears that the Municipality, for economy's sake, extinguishes several lamps in the streets after midnight, and consequently the town was far better off before with the petroleum lamps than it is at present. It is really very important for at least the landing-stages to be kept lighted up the whole night, as it must be taken into consideration that several steam launches belonging to steamship agencies embark and disembark passengers at any time before and after midnight. In order to avoid any accidents on account of the darkness, the lamps there should be left lighted during the whole night.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE
div.p: Two plague cases occurred during the week ending on the 8th inst. These cases, both of which were fatal, occurred at Port Said and El-Amar, in the Toukh district.

div.head: BOVINE TYPHUS
div.p: During the week ending December 8 there were 23 deaths from bovine typhus, an increase of 8 on the figures for the preceding week. During the corresponding week last year 984 head of cattle died from plague. The total deaths up to the 8th inst, are 146,616. 618 serum inoculations were made last week

div.head:
PORT OF ALEXANDRIA
PETITION TO LORD CROMER
div.p: In the petition addressed a few days ago to Lord Cromer, as Doyen of the Diplomatic and Consular Corps, by the International Chamber of Navigation at Alexandria, through its president, Mr. J. Ricard, the Chamber begins by pointing out the great advance which has been made of recent years in the trade of the port of Alexandria. They call his lordship's attention to the "considerable and continual prejudice caused to navigation and commerce by the inadequate quay accommodation provided, and appeal to his lordship's initiative to obtain - radical remedy for the present unsatisfactory state of things with as little loss of time 18 possible."

The petition then quotes figures showing the remarkable development in the shipping and trade of the port. The number of vessels entering and leaving the harbour rose from 2,112 in 1880 to 3,005 in 1903, and during this period the tonnage increased from 2,046,000 to 3,160,000, i. e. 50 per cent. With regard to merchandise, there was an increase in value From £.E.20,000,000 in 1884 to £.E.36,000,000 in 1904.

Everything pointed to the growing prosperity of Egypt, and under such conditions it was evident that the traffic in the port of Alexandria would go on increasing, keeping pace with the important works being carried out in the interior. The Chamber thinks that sufficient provision has not been made for this future development, and says that, notwithstanding the recent allocation in the 1905 Budget of a zum of £.E.178,000 for the improvement of the port and customs accommodation, it will be a long time before the authorities will be able to cope, by what they call half measures, with the rapid and certain development of trade.

The Chamber then points out the difficulties which steamers have to contend with in the port, owing to lack of berth space. The movements of ships are considerably hindered and the unloading of the vessels is sometimes carried out with the greatest difficulty. This deplorable situation has been most keenly felt by the timber-carrying steamers. Notwithstanding the enormous increase in the imports of wood, no new quay has been built for the unloading of these steamers during the past year. The captains of eleven of these steamers, several of which lay in the harbour over a month, have recently had recourse to the Mixed Courts,and other vessels, belonging to regular lines, which would not accost the quays nor find lighters to unload, have had to delay discharging for a considerable time. The situation has therefore become incontestably acute, and it can only rapidly become more so. In the Chamber's opinion, it calls for, not partial or provisional measures, but the immediate adoption of an elaborate plan, and the granting of sufficient sums to put the port of Alexandria as soon as possible in a condition to cope with every eventuality.

In conclusion, the Chamber suggests the institution of a special Commission, on which would be represented all interested parties, to consider the present situation in every detail and draw up & plan capable of meeting, as soon as possible, all the requirements which the continual development of shipping and commerce may necessitate.

div.head: GHIZEH PYRAMIDS
div.p: A very interesting view of the ancient burying-ground at Ghizeh Pyramids has been opened to aid the exhaustive researches being made by Prof. Reisner. No visitor to Egypt this winter should miss looking at this exposed site, dating from B.C. 4250, as it will be recovered again as soon as the researches are completed.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, will be given next Saturday. Several dinner parties have already been ordered for that evening at the Savoy restaurant. A large number of visitors are arriving this week, many being former residents of the Savoy, among them Mr. and Mrs. Paravicini, the Misses Hurley, Mr. and Mrs. Peckham, | Mr. Look, Mr. and Mrs. W.A.Hoppin, &c. Sir Samuel Montague and party are expected at the Savoy Hotel on the 21st inst., arriving at Port Said by the S.S. Britannia. The annual dinner of the Grecia Masonic Lodge will take place at the hotel on Tuesday, January 10.

div.head: "THE ARABIAN NIGHTS"
div.p: The sixteenth and concluding volume of the French translation of "The Arabian Nights," by Dr. J. C. Mardrus, has just been issued by M. Fasquelle. The only possible rival to this "Mille Nuits et une Nuit'' is Burton's English version, while M. Mardrus, who, like Burton, has worked from the best texts procurable and has not ruined his work in the attempt to adapt it for family reading, has at the same time shown a somewhat less aggressive disregard for the moral susceptibilities of the general reader than was evident in the work of Burton, more especially in the "anthropological” notes.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Amasis sailed from Malta yesterday at noon and is due here on Friday morning with general cargo and coal from Glasgow.
The Moss liner Seti sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon, bound for Liverpool.

div.head:
NOTES FROM SUAKIN
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: The British S.S. Guildhall arrived here on 28th ulto, from England with material for the Suakin-Atbara Railway, such as iron bridges, sleepers, etc.

Miralai Macauley Bey, Director of the Sudan Railways, was a passenger by the Guildhall from Suez to Suakin. On Macaplay Bey's arrival here Bimbashi Longfield, R.E., Assistant Director, Sudan Railways, returned to RailI head, which is now about 40 miles away from Suakin, this being the third station.
Bimbashi Lord, R.E., has had a relapse and is still confined to his room.

The Suakin condensers are still followed by ill-luck. I mentioned lately the arrival of Mr. Maylor to put them up. He was the third engineer sent out from England for that purpose, the former two having had to return home as being medically unfit for Suakin. As soon as Mr. Maylor arrived he caught fever and was laid up for several days. I am glad to say he is now better.
The Europeans resident here are greatly increasing in numbers, more especially Englishmen, most of whom are in the Government service.

Several bars, provision stores,and restaurants have been opened since the beginning of last month. Amongst them may be noted the New Bar and provision stores of Mr. "George, the Splendid Bar of Mr. Capato, the well-known contractor, and the Grand Suakin Restaurant of Mr. Elia, the caterer for the Government steamers on the Shellal-Wady Halfa reach.

Last week we had constant rain. The weather is now mild and cool. The fields are beginning to look green, and we expect plenty of vegetables and fruit this winter. All the cattle are now out on the hills grazing, and milk and butter are getting plentiful and cheap in the market.

div.head: A.L.M. & D.S.
div.p: OPENING CONCERT OF SEASON. "A thorough and well-deserved success," was the unanimous verdict of all those privileged to be present at the opening concert of the above well-known society given at Abbat's Hotel last Saturday night. The feature of the evening was the début of the newly-formed Choral Union, whose performance reflected the greatest credit on their able conductor Mr. Sarjeant, to whose efforts their striking success is without doubt due. Owing to the scarcity of copies of the part-songs given on Saturday, the number of those taking part was necessarily small. However, & quantity of music is expected to arrive shortly from England, and the Choral Union will then be doubtless greatly augmented. This en passant. The concert opened with a chorus from Barnett's Ancient Mariner entitled “The Ship was cheered." This was well rendered by members of the Choral Union (Lady Blomfield, Miss MunGavin, Miss Cree, Miss Steiger, Mrs. Roberts, Miss Neil, Miss Smith, Mesers. J. Purvis, A. H. Jennings, H. M. Blomfield, P. Byrne, L. Nixon, W. S. Watt, and E. P. Rees. Mr. Edgar Fiteni followed with two solos on the violin. It was unfortunate that his charming rendering of Svendsen's well-known Romance should have been somewhat marred by the accompaniment, which had evidently not been carefully studied. Auber's "La Muta di Portici," how-a ever, was well performed by soloist and accompanist alike and much appreciated. A song by Mr. Byrne was the next on the list. This was “The Rosary" by Nevin, and was given with great taste and feeling. The last two items of Part I were reserved for the two "stars" of the evening. Mrs. Haddad played two pianoforte solos, one by Henselt, "Si oiseau j'étais à toi je volerais," which was followed by a Romance of Rubinstein. These she played with all her accustomed skill, the Romance being particularly well rendered. Mrs. Cree brought this part of the concert to a close with two songs in which she delighted her audience. The first, a charming little song accompanied by the composer, M. Felix, and the second "Chanson Tsigane, " by Brahms, which had to be repeated.

Part II. opened with the well-known part song "An Old Romance" by Mendelssohn. This was admirably rendered by the Choral Union, and must have gladdened the heart of their genial conductor. In response to the demands of the audience it was repeated with even greater success. Two violin solos now followed, both delightfully played by Miss E. Lang-Anderson. Great credit is due to her for playing her first piece so well in spite of unfortunate interruptions from an adjacent window. However, the "gamins” in the street being dispersed, the audience were able to enjoy uninterruptedly her excellent performance of Carl Bobm's well-known "Perpetuo Mobile," which was heartily encored. Mrs. Cree once more enchanted her audience with a beautiful rendering of Beethoven's "Adelaide." Being of course recalled, she repeated the song with as great success as ever. Mr. Byrne followed with a charming little ditty about "Two eyes of blue," from The Silver Slipper. As an encore be sang "The Pearl of Sweet Ceylon," from The Cingalee, in & style worthy of Mr. Haydn Coffin. A wonderful performance of Liszt's "Rhapsodie Hongroise" was Mrs. Haddad's second contribution. Her audience demanded a further exhibition of this talented player's powers, but owing to the lateness of the hour Mrs. Haddad decided not to treat her hearers to an encore. The last item on the programme was a beautiful song composed by the singer's sister, Mrs. Dandridge, which Mr. Sarjeant rendered with great feeling. The National Anthem, sung with much "verve" by a patriotic trio at the end of the concert-room, brought a highly successful concert to a close. The heartiest thanks of the society are due to Mr. Abbat for so kindly placing the room at their disposal for the evening.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Hon. G. A.Riddle, American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, arrived this morning at Alexandria by the North German Lloyd's 3.8. Schleswig and left for Cairo by the 9 a.m. train.

Baron Max Oppenheim, Imperial Councillor of Legation to the German Diplomatic Agency et Cairo, arrived at Alexandria from Europe by the Austrian Lloyd steamer and resumed his official duties at Cairo to-day.
Hassan Pasha Mohsen has left Cairo for Assouan, where he intends staying about three weeks.
Crookshank Pasha left Assouan on Thursday evening for Halfa and Khartoum, and will return to Cairo on the 20th inst.
El Kaimakam J. S. Liddell Bey, Sudan Civil Administration, having been appointed Assistant Inspector General of Telegraphs, Egyptian Government, is struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army.
Mr. and Mrs. Dans Estes left Cairo yesterday for Agsouan, where they will remain until the New Year.

Mrs. William McMillån, wife of the well-known explorer, who has been travelling with her husband in Central Africa, is at Claridge's Hotel, London, at present, where she is making a sojourn of some weeks. A marriage is arranged, and will shortly take place quite quietly, between Normen Dewar-Durie, second son of the late Andrew Dewar-Durie, M. D, of Craigluscar, Dunfermline, Fife, and Isabelle, youngest daughter of the late Francis W. Rowsell, C. B., C. M. G., barrister-at-law, and formerly Director of Naval Contracts, and British Commissioner of the Egyptian State Domains.

Captain and Brevet Major Sir E. P. C. Girouard, K.C.M.G., D.S.O., Royal Engineers, has been granted the brevet of Lieutenant Colonel, for distinguished services of an exceptional nature other than in the Field.
Mr. C. J. Alford has joined the board of the Central Egypt Exploration Company.

Amongst the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice Mr. and Mrs. Neel, Mr. C.O. Hebb, Mr. W. Vincent, Mr. Triolean, the Misses Norman, Mrs. and Miss Muzzy, Mrs. Cotiquan, the Misses MacLean, Mrs. Hawthorn, Prof. Dr. Schweinfurth, Sanitätsrat Dr. and Frau Weber, Mr. Bacarat, and Mr. Bayer.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN SPINNING AND WEAVING COY. LIMITED
div.p: Voici le rapport de l'assemblée générale ordinaire du 12 Décembre de l'exercici 1903-1904, terminé le 30 Septembre dernier :

Cet exercice se solde par une perte de L.E. 8.159.460. En comparant ce chiffre de perte avec celui de l'exercice précédent, vous pourrez apprécier la valeur des progrès réalisés au cours de l'année 1903-1904.
La perte du Bilan 1902-1903 était de L.E. 6.740.709, c'est-à-dire de plus du double de celle du Bilan 1903-1904.

Pour tirer des offres de ce dernier Bilan des éléments d'appréciation de la situation présente et des avances d'avenir de votre affaire, il y a lieu,croyons-nous,d'attribuer une signification particulière au fait que: Tandis que le compte de fabrication “Manufacturing Account" soldait en 1902 1903 par une perte de L.E. 2.548.942, il solde en 1903-1904 par un bénéfice de L.E. 1.946.009. Cette constatation met en évidence que notre perte finale est due presque entièrement à l'insuffisance d'offres de notre production par rapport à celui de nos frais généraux.

Comme ces frais généraux — dans le limite où nous nous efforçons de les maintenir - ne sont susceptibles d'aucune réduction substantielle, c'est uniquement du développement de notre production qu none devons attendre la prospérité, albatraoz tion faite, bien entendu, des circonstances générales plus ou moins favorables à l'industrie textile. En d'autres termes, c'est toujours le problème de la main-d'oeuvre que nous avons à résoudre.

Ainsi que nous l'avons déjà expliqué aux Assemblées précédentes, les difficultés qui présente ce problème ne peuvent disparaître que graduellement. La population ouvrière qui nous est nécessaire ne peut se former que par sélection dans la masse des éléments hétérogènes qui passent par notre fabrique. C'est une formation d'antapı plus lente que les ouvriers qui entrent chez nous n'ont pas de racines à Alexandrie, sauf quelques rares exceptions. Ils sont, à cause de cela, difficiles à fixer.

Cette question ouvrière nous a causé encore de fréquentes déceptions au coure de la dernière campagne et a paralysé partiellement notre production. Nous nour attendons à la voir pour longtemps encore contrecarrer nos progrès, mais le noyau d'ouvriers qui paraît définitivement acquis, après tous les déchets, nous autorise à espérer que notre situation sous le rapport: essentiel de la msin-d'æuyre, deviendra de moins en moins mauvaise et que nou aurons efpia la satisfaction d'établir pou: l'année 1904-1905 un Bilan sans perte, ou peut-être même le premier Bilan soldap!

Le chiffre de nos ventes & dépassé de 6 000 L E. celui de l'exercice précéder t La supériorité de nos tissus fabriqués avec le coton Egyptien sur les ti8808 importés fabriqués en Europe avec des cotons Indiens et Américains & déjà été constatée à l'usage par les indigènes dans quelques villages. Ce fait nous a été rapporté d divers côtés. Si nous ne bénéficions pas encore de la préférence corrélative à la Supériorité de notre matière première, nous en bénéficierons certainement plus tard. Le jour viendra ou, au lieu. d'être obligés de vendre nos articles un peu meilleur marché que les articles similaires importés, nous pourrons les vendre plus cher en rai. Bon de leur durée.

La question de vente ne nous préoccupe dono pas. Nous croyons n'avoir à envisager que celle d'une promotion économique, c'est-à-dire d'une grande production et nous espérons que nos efforts vers ce but seront couronnés de succès avec le temps.

div.head: Alexandria Water Company
DIVIDENDE INTERIMAIRE
div.p: Un dividende intérimaire de deux shel. lings et six pence par action de $5 et de dix abellings par action de £ 20 est payable le 15 courant, sur présentation des coupons de cette échéance à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ld. à Alexandrie.

Afin de donner suite à la décision de l'Assemblée Général Extraordinaire da 27 Mars 1889, par laquelle chaque action d £20 fat convertie en 4 actions de £5, et à la demande du Stock Exchange de Londres, qui en donnant la cote aux actions de la Compagnie & exigé qu’ tondre les actions de la Cie formeraient partie d'une seul série de Nos. de 1 à 100,000; il devient absolument nécessaire de présenter tous les titres de £ 20, afin d'y sombrer les nus. Veaux numéros et d'attacher aux titres une nouvelle feuille de coupons représentant quatre actions chacune portant Boeri ate numéros.

Pour cette raison MM. les porteurs de titres de £20 sont priés de présenter à l'anglo Egyptian Bank Ld. d' Alexandrie, I urs titres de £ 20 en même temps que 1 coupon da 16 courant, et la Banque leur donnera en échange ton certificat de dépôt. contre le retour duquel les titres de $20 seront rendus aux propriétaires monis dkouseanz numéros et coupons.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(AUJOURD'HUI A MIDI ET DEMI)
div.p: La séance d'hier après-midi a été une débâcle. Ce matin les cours se sont un peu relevés et le marché est plus ferme, mais on ne s'attend à aucune reprise importante d'ici à la fin des fêtes.
La Banque avait fléchi hier à 22 8/16. Elle débute à ce prix, atteint 22 5/8 et clôture à 22 8/8 acheteurs. On a échangé environ 1,500 titres.
De 10 la Banque Agricole monte à 10 5/82 pour clôturer à 10 3/32. On a fait un millier de titres.
La Delta débute à 14 7/16, atteint 14 11/16 et clôture à un prix légèrement inférieur, 14 5/8. 8 à 400 actions ont été échangées dans la matinée.

On peut en dire autant de la plupart des autres valeurs. La Daïra Sanieh, qui était tombée à 21 1/16, reprend aujourd'hui à 21 5/16; la Salt & Sod remonte également de 88/6 à 39/6 et ainsi pour plusieurs autres valeurs.

La baisse s'accentue, au contraire, pour la Delta Land de 8 5/8 à 3 9/16, pour la Orown Brewery de 224 à 217, pour la Brasserie des Pyramides de 115 à 114, pour les Eaux d'Alexandrie de 16 8/4 à 16 1/2, pour les Eaux du Caire de 1100 à 1080 et pour les Tramways Privilégiées de 140 à 186.
L. Filature reste stationnaire à 8/4, les Cotton Mills à 7/6 acheteurs, et les Markets à 22/6.
De 12: où elle est tombée hier, la Ban. d'Athènes remonte ce matin à 126 acheteurs.

div.head: GUNNY BAG MARKET
div.p: SHRAGER Bros.' CALCUTTA MARKET REPORT
FOR WEEK ENDING 10th DECEMBER, 1904.

The Gunny market has continued firm. Trade requirements have enhanced prices of E bags for this month, which, coupled with an active demand from Bombay, clearing bazaar holders of their carry-over of 2 lb B Twills, has strengthened the forward position materially, and there are now more speculative buyers than sellers. Some mills are in a rather awkward position in respect to their supplies of Jute, for although they are well secured on paper, they have reason for anxiety in respect to deliveries.
Export demand has been moderate, but enquiries have been coming in from all consuming centres and full prices have been paid for prompt shipment.
The country trade promises to be a large one, and must tend to maintain the advanced cost of Jute fabrics.

HESSIANS are steady and demand has been moderate, but full prices are being paid for nine and eleven porter cloth for Jany/June, while the small parcels of 105 oz cloth available for this month are almost worked off. Wheat bags have been taken up at Rs. 12-8 as offered, while a line of Cotton Packs for the forward months has also been secured at the equivalent of 40" 8 oz cloth, and more are wanted, but not readily obtainable, which shows the strong position of sellers.
We quote :

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT STEAMERS AND BOATS
div.p: The Sudan Government steamer service has been discontinued as a tourist service, but a steamer will leave Khartoum for Gondokoro Uganda, on the 15th of each month, and will run approximately according to the time-table published.

The steamer scheduled to leave Khartoum on the 15th January and 15th February is fitted with excellent accommodation for passengers in double-berthed cabins. A competent steward and staff of servants will be carried and a first class cuisine will be provided. The steamer is fitted throughout with electric light and has hot and cold water baths.

Steamers carry Government passengers and freight, towing barges for this purpose when necessary. Times and stations of call are dependent on the requirements of Government service, but the itinerary is adhered to fairly closely and the convenience and comfort of passengers will be considered as much as possible. Steamers will not carry a doctor.

div.head: SUDAN MINES, LIMITED
div.p: The Sudan Mines, Limited, has been floated with a capital of £60,000, one-third of which, on the basis allowed and desired by the Sudan Government, has been set aside for working capital.

The company's concession, over which it has the sole prospecting rights under a licence which will be granted direct by the Sudan Government, for four years, comprises an area of about 8,000 square miles. One advantage is that it has a coast line of 130 miles, and no part of its area is a further distance than 80 miles from the coast. The large natural harbour of Mahommed Ghul gives access to the heart of the concession, and large steamers are able to go in at any time. No less than seven extensive areas of old workings scattered evenly over (the whole concesssion have been located, and in every case gold has been proved to exist in the dumps or surface workings. The greatest development work has been confined to the old workings named "Gabait." Many reefs containing high values have been discovered, and the intention of the company is to fully prospect and develop these old workings at once. An expedition will leave England within the next few days under the management of Mr. Noel Griffin, who has already spent two seasons on the concession.

It is expected that the country will be rapidly opened up now that railway communication is assured in the near future, not the least important project being the line from Berber to Suakin, which is in course of construction and will run a little to the south of the concession. Among other advantages that will accrue to the company through its accessibility to the sea, not the least relates to economy in mining. Coal can be landed at Mohommed Ghul at a cost of only 20s. per ton, and all other materials in proportion, so that transport charges are not likely to form an excessive item in exploiting the concession. It is not too much to say that the company is starting on its career under very favourable auspices, and with every prospect of being highly successful.

div.head: "WHO'S WHO" FOR 1905
div.p: The approach of 1905 is heralded by a new edition of that invaluable compendium of current biography "Who's Who," which now extends to over 1,700 pages. The completeness of the work is seen in the careful way in which Egypt is attended to. Besides notices of the Khedive, Lord Cromer, and the Sirdar, there are careful compilations of the careers of Sir William Garstin, Sir Elwin Palmer, Sir Horace Pinching, Crookshank Pasha, the Judicial Adviser, Captain McMurdo, Coles Pasha, Mr. Boyle, Dean Butcher, Mr. Foster, Sir William Willcocks, Chitty Bey and many other well-known Anglo-Egyptian officials, all given in detail and with accuracy. The only errors we have noticed are Helmé for Hilmy and Koubach for Koubbeh, in the account of the Khedive.
"Who's Who." London: Adam and Charles Black, Boho-square. 7s. 6d. nett,

div.head: FOOTBALL
div.p: ROYAL BERKS "D" COMPANY V. SAINT ANDREW's.

Considerable interest was manifested in this fixture, which was brought off on the parade ground at Mustapha on Saturday. Saint Andrew's were under fall strength and when it was seen that “D” Company had an exceptionally strong eleven in the field, it looked as though they would romp home. Saint Andrew's started the game, and Savage and Ferris were called upon to defend at the outset. The pressure was, however, mild and the Saints soon got a retaliative pressure. Gough was getting things pretty much all his own way, but Bright was always there to clinch his parting effort. From one of these break-away runs Appleby was called upon to handle. From the kick out Partridge got well away and some nice wing play by Cowie and Hutchins brought them within range of Paine. Partridge's shot lacked sting, however, and play was again transferred to midfield. Here the teams clinched helplessly for a bit, but Nixon seized the opportunity to pilot the ball towards Paine. His shot just missed by inches. Belcher and Grant now got away on the home left and Fitzgerald and Sweet were sorely tried. They eventually cleared and Cowie got a chance but put past. Uninteresting were the proceedings now for something like five minutes, till Nixon again got possession, and, slipping Lewis, again tested Paine with a beauty. The custodian cleared and Gough and Fox retaliated at the other end. Fox had hard lines in not scoring, the ball hitting the har. The homesters still hovered round the Saints' goal and for a time it looked as though they must score. Fitzgerald came to the rescue and Hutchins got possession, putting in a shot which Paine "foozled” badly, thus enabling Tulloch to screw right across the goal mouth, but no one was near to convert. Both teams were now doing a lot of pressing but both defences were playing a sound game. Savage tried to force matters for his side, and although he showed some tricky play he seldom managed to make much headway. A foul against George for handling looked very bad for the visitors, but Ferris put over. Half-time arrived with the homesters pressingno score.

Bright remodelled his team for the second half, recognising that he would require all the defence possible. Cowie was brought into the half-back line, and George went forward. The homesters were also bent on penetrating the defence in this half, and with this object in view Savage was brought forward. From the kick-off the homesters pressed, but the Saints' detence was not to be caught napping. Nixon and Cowie for a time had to bear the brunt of the front rank pressure, but so well did they perform their duties that the homesters had to retire. The tackling was of a very high order at this stage, halves and backs combining beautifully. Partridge, who was playing a nice forcing game, now got away and passing to Hutchins, gave that player a good opportunity for putting in. Paine ran Lout to clear, and George taking up the ball, netted it before the custodian had returned to his charge. This unlooked-for reverse made the homesters double their efforts to break through to Appleby. Gough put well across, and Grant with the goal at his mercy delayed too long so that Appleby had time to prepare for his parting shot, which he cleared without difficulty. Appleby was by no means idle now, and everything that came to him was treated in finished style. He has & reckless bearing which commends him, and he never hesitates. With Bright and Fitzgerald in front of him the trio formed a fine defence. Both teams were now having a "look-in,” but despite all efforts no further scoring took place.
It was a fairly evenly contested game throughout, but the Saints found the net and this carried the day. Both sides adopted the rushing style as their tactics, and both

In fairness to the home quintette it should be said that the whole line played with about equal ability, but Gough merits notice from the fact that he was kept under strict supervision by Nixon, Cowie, and Bright. div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for thr opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: CHRISTIANITY IN THE SUDAN
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Sir, -Your occasional correspondent at Khartoum says that "Christianity can do much good in the Sudan, and Government should give every assistance it can to missionaries who want to establish stations here." I think the writer and those who share his views should be reminded that, in the opinion of Lord Cromer, manifest political objections exist to allowing mission work in those provinces of the Sudan whose population is Mohamedan. "I entirely agree," says his lordship, "with the opinion held by Sir Reginald Wingate, and shared, I believe, by every responsible official, who can speak with local knowledge and authority on the subject, that the time is still distant when mission work can, with safety and advantage, be permitted amongst the Moslem population of the Sudan." (Egypt No. 1, 1903, page 90).

There is no mistaking the meaning of the above. It is likewise shrewd common-sense. Bearing in mind the numbers of "little wars" in which missionaries have involved the British nation, it seems to me highly essential to give pause to their well-meaning but mistaken zeal. There is work to be done nearer home if we but know how to do it. We should set our own house in order before trying to convert the Moslems.
I am, etc.,

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
SERVICES SANITAIRES
AVIS
div.p: Il est rappelé aux vendeurs des substances vénéneuses déjà autorisés en vertu de l'arrêté du 13 Juin 1891 qu'il est nécessaire d'obtenir de nouvelles autorisations dans le délai de 90 jours à partir de la publication du Décret du 15 Septembre qui eut lieu dans le Journal Officiel français le 19 Septembre 1904 et dans le Journal Officiel arabe le 21 du même mois. Les autorisations qu'ils détiennent actuellement seront donc nulles après le 21 Décembre 1904,

L'examen qu'auront à subir les vendeurs de substances vénéneuses, conformément à l'art. 12, avant d'obtenir les autorisations nécessaires, aura lieu pour la ville d'Alexandrie le lundi de chaque mois à l'Hôpital du Gouverne. ment.
Exceptionnellement les premiers examens auront lieu dans le dit établissement les 14 et 19 Décembre 1904 à 9 h. a.m.
Les personnes sollicitant l'autorisation de faire le commerce des substances vénéneuses devront justifier des connaissances suivantes :
1° Connaître toutes les dispositions du Règlement sur la vente des substances vénéneuses.
2° Savoir lire et écrire sous dictée les noms de toutes les substances mentionnées dans le Tableau II annexé au Règlement.
3° Connaitre parfaitement les poids et mesures du système métrique.

4° Savoir distinguer 15 articles au moins des substances suivantes : Cobalte, (arsen-métallique), acide arsénieux, Realgar (sulfure rouge d'arsenic), Auripigment (sulfure jaune d'arsenio), Acide hydrocyanique, Cyanure de potasse, Bichlorure de mercure, Bisulfate de mercure, Oxide mercurique jaune, Oxide mercurique rouge, Acétate de plomb, Sulfate de zinc, Chlorure de zinc, Tartre stibié, Acétate de cuivre, Phosphore, Chloroforme, Acide picrique, Acide oxalique.
5° Expliquer l'usage des substances mentionnées dans le Tableau II et dire comment elles doivent être renfermées et étiquetées.
6° Pouvoir tenir régulièrement les registres pour la vente des substances vénéneuses.

Les personnes qui subiront avec succès l'examen précité pourront obtenir l'autorisation nécessaire pour la vente des substances vénéneuses. Toutefois l'autorisation ne sera délivrée aux intéressés qu'après que l'autorité sanitaire ce sera assurée que le local destiné à la vente est bien aéré et non humide, qu'il est propre et que le nom de la personne autorisée est lisiblement écrit sur le devant du local.

Les personnes désirant obtenir l'autorisation de vendre une ou diverses substances vénéneuses devront être tenues à distinguer seulement les articles pour lesquels l'autorisation est sollicitée, et dans le cas où l'autorisation est accordée, il sera nettement stipulé sur la permission que le porteur est autorisé à vendre seulement ces substances et aucunes autres. Alexandrie, le 6 Décembre 1904.
L'Administratour, (Sign6) W. P. CHATAWAY.
